awd_titl_txt: Planning IUCRC at Harvard University:  Center for Biological Applications of Solid-State Systems (CBASS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Moore's Law scaling of semiconductor technology has been the single biggest driver of economic growth worldwide through its revolutionary impact on communications and computation. At the same time, discovery and technological activity in the life sciences has exploded. Life sciences efforts have, however, benefited little from advances in semiconductor technologies beyond the dramatic improvements in computation infrastructure and higher performance cameras for microscopy. The Center on Biological Applications of Solid-State Systems (C-BASS) seeks to transform both the biotechnology and semiconductor sectors by forging new connections between these two largely disjoint ecosystems and by training a generation of scientists and engineers well versed in both fields. The center proposes a comprehensive research program designed to expand and train the workforce required to implement this vision, while creating new technologies.  

At Harvard University, the Center will be supported by the integrated activities of companies and research institutions across semiconductor, biotechnology, and other related industries. The results of the C-BASS effort will transform a range of fields including biology, biomedical engineering, semiconductor technology, and medicine by developing a range of new sensing systems that take advantage of the small scale and high performance of nanoelectronics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The C-BASS IUCRC seeks to forge connections between biotechnology and semiconductor sectors and train scientists and engineers in both fields. We proposed a comprehensive research and development ecosystem, designed to train the workforce required to implement this vision, while creating new technologies. Our planning meeting brought together stakeholders from educational institutions, companies, manufacturing partners, and venture capitalists as potential members to discuss key areas.

The planning meeting (hybrid) was held on April 18 and 19, 2022, hosted by CUNY’s ASRC and co-chaired by three PI’s, Shepard (Columbia), Ham (Harvard) and Ulijn (CUNY). The program (Figure 1) included introductions to three focus areas and pitches made by trainees from the three institutions. Industry and DoD representatives were invited to comment on presentations and indicate interest levels in various projects (Figure 2). Discussions were held to help identify focus areas, industry pain points, and how the center could help benefit industry. There was a feedback session with Dr. Prakash Balan from NSF. Responses to questions posed are below.

Main conclusions:

- There is interest from industry and DoD labs in developing biomedical technologies that integrate semiconductor technology with biology.

- The proposed biosensors and medical devices are complex and small companies may not have capital and R&D know-how to develop prototypes. The center could play a key role.

- The chemical and materials aspect of the bio-semiconductor interface needs particular attention. 

- The discussion with the program director suggested that the IUCRC model may not be most suited to the C-BASS objectives, with several issues identified, including IP handling, technology readiness levels, and insufficiently defined industry pain points.  

Response to questions posed:

Q1. The fusion of biotech and semiconductor research will provide a unique training opportunity for students, post-docs, and PIs. The research and tools developed should be of use for better understanding of basic biology broadly and medical research very directly. However, there is significant concern that the breadth of this combination will be a challenge to bring together particularly given the heavy IP creation focus of the planned center. A better use of the IUCRC funding could be focused on the upstream pre-competitive aspects focused on knowledge creation that will feed downstream and more proprietary use of the knowledge and for this activity to be truly collaborative as opposed to a collection of proprietary projects. How will the center drive an agenda that will ensure that the IUCRC program’s needs for collaborative funding by industry of pre-competitive research is ensured as opposed to direct technology development projects (such activities would typically be downstream and derivative from center research activities). Please address this concern and clarify the internal thinking on the mission and vision for this proposed center. 

This is the fundamental challenge for what relies on industrial funding. Companies may demand nearer-term deliverables, while tolerating or supporting some longer-term projects. C-BASS would seek to achieve this balance. Ideally projects will bridge non-competing companies (one from semiconductor and one biotechnology). This will help move projects away from things that would be considered “proprietary” or single-company-focused. We seek to create these linkages.

Q2. Proposed projects are substantially driven by electronics engineering PIs. There was strong consensus that the multi-university team seemed in need of bolstering the team’s capabilities related to biological recognition and would benefit from bringing on more expertise in this key focus area. The team appears engineering heavy and may need better balance across the biological sciences and to leverage the properties of biological systems for computing, integrated circuit design, and data storage. Please discuss/comment on these concerns. 

C-BASS seeks to use capabilities of semiconductor industry to create new tools for biology, so the projects are indeed engineering focused. While semiconductor industry is EE focused in general, C-BASS faculty are not all electronics people but include, for example, chemical, biomedical, and materials researchers. We recruited faculty from biological sciences to drive key application areas, and we would continue to build on this. Applications of biology to problems in information technology is not our current focus, but we may entertain this possibility.

Q3. Please clarify the Intellectual Property agreement, especially licensing credits. 

The approach is deemed straightforward. Industrial Partners is the Intellectual Property agreement, which grants Partner credits worth ten-times the cumulative membership fees paid for the licensing of intellectual property generated by C-BASS.

Q4. While there was identifiable merit in the proposed center, there is concern that this center is seeking to bring together vastly different industrial communities/cultures into a single center and driving a convergent agenda to achieve the center’s goals.  How will the team manage through this issue?

This is the challenge and the need for C-BASS.  We have done it already with key start-up ventures. The enthusiastic participation of many industrial partners also indicates that we have tapped into an unmet need.
